intro: Primula vulgaris subsp. vulgaris, commonly known as the common primrose, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Europe, western Asia, and northern Africa. It typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm and features rosettes of broadly ovate, hairy leaves. The plant produces clusters of bell-shaped, five-petaled flowers in shades of yellow, orange, and white, which bloom from late winter to early summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and partial to full shade, often found in woodland habitats. The species is valued for its ornamental appeal and has been widely cultivated in gardens across temperate regions.
